content: The Cameron Gulbransen Kids Transportation Safety Act of 2007, also known as the K.T. Safety Act of 2007, mandates the consideration of safety standards for power windows in motor vehicles to prevent accidents involving children and others. The Secretary of Transportation must initiate a rulemaking within 18 months and prescribe safety standards within 30 months if deemed reasonable and appropriate. The Secretary must prescribe safety standards for power windows in vehicles within 30 months if deemed reasonable. If no additional standards are necessary, a report must be transmitted to relevant committees, and information on vehicle safety features must be made public. The Secretary will revise FMVSS 111 to improve rearward visibility for drivers to detect areas behind vehicles, reducing accidents involving small children and disabled persons. This may involve adding mirrors, sensors, or cameras. The Secretary will establish safety standards to improve rearward visibility for drivers of motor vehicles, including the use of additional mirrors, sensors, or cameras. Compliance with these standards must be achieved within 48 months of the final rule being issued. Different types of motor vehicles may have varying phase-in periods based on data showing their frequency in accidents. The Secretary will establish safety standards for rearward visibility, considering different types of motor vehicles based on accident data. Priority may be given to certain vehicle types, with regulations specifying the order and percentages of phase-in. Motor vehicles with automatic transmission post-September 1, 2010, must have a system requiring the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". After September 1, 2010, motor vehicles with automatic transmissions must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". From September 1, 2010 onwards, motor vehicles with automatic transmissions must have a system that requires the brake to be depressed before shifting out of "park". Manufacturers must submit information on noncompliant vehicles to the Secretary, who will publish the make and model of such vehicles to the public. The Act defines a motor vehicle as per section 30102(a)(6) of title 49, United States Code, excluding motorcycles, trailers, and vehicles over 10,000 pounds. The database established under the Act includes information on injuries and deaths from nontraffic, noncrash events involving motor vehicles. The Secretary must make this information available to the public. Additionally, a child safety information program must be provided within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must provide information on hazards to children in nontraffic, noncrash incidents by supplementing or creating a consumer information program. The program must utilize relevant data to establish priorities, address risks like back over incidents and hyperthermia, and make information available to the public. If deadlines cannot be met, new deadlines must be established.
